column2: This movie is a love letter to Paris. The opening montage is just stunning.
The twist that Adriana also has her own 'golden age' (the Belle Époque) that she wants to escape to is brilliant.
Owen Wilson is perfect as Gil. He has that neurotic, romantic writer vibe down.
Gil breaking up with Inez and deciding to stay in Paris is the perfect ending for his character arc.
The whole concept of meeting your literary and artistic heroes is a dream come true.
The reveal that every generation romanticizes a past era is the central theme of the movie. So smart.
Woody Allen's dialogue is so witty and charming.
The final scene of Gil walking in the rain with Gabrielle is a perfect, hopeful ending.
The costumes and set designs for the 1920s are incredible.
Adriana choosing to stay in the 1890s, while Gil realizes he needs to live in the present, is a great divergence.
The scene with Salvador Dalí is comedy gold. 'I see a rhinoceros!'
The ending is a beautiful message about finding your own 'golden age' in the present.
The contrast between Gil's magical nights and his mundane days is so well done.
The way Gil finally gets the validation he needs from Gertrude Stein is a great moment.
The movie is just pure escapism and charm.
The plot twist with Paul being a 'pedantic' fraud, and Inez cheating with him, is so satisfying for Gil's character.
The soundtrack is perfect. It really captures the mood of Paris.
The final walk in the rain is Gil finally embracing the present moment he always dreamed of.
Inez and her parents are so insufferable. You're just waiting for Gil to leave them.
The movie is a beautiful exploration of nostalgia and the illusion of a 'perfect' past.
The casting of all the historical figures is spot-on.
The ending shows that true happiness is found in accepting and living in your own time.
The movie is like a warm, cozy dream.
Gil's realization that there is no perfect time is the big breakthrough he needed as a writer and a person.
The scenes in the 1920s are so vibrant and full of life.
The way he gets to have his manuscript read by his heroes is every writer's fantasy.
The film is a charming and intelligent comedy.
The ending is a perfect representation of 'The moveable feast' that Paris is.
The way the magical car just shows up at midnight is such a simple but effective device.
Gil choosing the present over a romanticized past is a huge moment of growth.
The dialogue is so sharp and funny.
The final scene is a quiet, romantic, and perfect conclusion.
The movie is a delightful and whimsical journey through time.
The way Adriana is just as dissatisfied with her present as Gil is with his is a great parallel.
The film is a celebration of art, literature, and the city that inspires it.
The ending is a beautiful reminder that the 'good old days' are happening right now.
The supporting cast of historical figures is a who's who of artistic genius.
The final walk in the rain with Gabrielle feels like the start of Gil's real story.
The movie is just so clever and well-written.
The 'golden age thinking' concept is so insightful and true.
The visuals of Paris, both in the present and the past, are gorgeous.
The ending is a perfect, romantic resolution for a character who was searching for himself.
The film is a joy to watch from beginning to end.
The way Gil solves the mystery of Adriana's diary is a great little detective subplot.
The movie is a charming and funny look at our relationship with the past.
The final scene is a perfect example of 'happily ever after' without being cliché.
The surrealist party with Dalí, Man Ray, and Buñuel is a highlight.
The ending is a beautiful statement about the importance of living in the now.
The movie is a perfect escape for anyone who loves art and history.
The realization that nostalgia is a trap is the central message of the film.
The way the film brings the 1920s to life is magical.
The final scene feels so earned after Gil's journey of self-discovery.
A charming, witty, and surprisingly deep film.
The twist that Adriana's 'golden age' is just another past that people in that time romanticized is brilliant.
The movie is a beautiful and funny exploration of creativity and inspiration.
The ending, with Gil finding a kindred spirit in the present, is so satisfying.
The dialogue about nostalgia is some of Woody Allen's best.
The final walk in the rain is the most romantic scene in the whole movie.
The film is a whimsical and wonderful trip through Paris.
The central theme about the 'golden age' fallacy is so well-executed.
The casting is perfect, especially Adrien Brody as Dalí.
The ending is a quiet and beautiful resolution to Gil's internal conflict.
A masterpiece of romantic comedy.
The way the movie deconstructs nostalgia is so smart.
The film is a visual and intellectual treat.
The final scene is a perfect, understated moment of connection.
The movie is a charming and insightful look at the stories we tell ourselves about the past.
The ending is a beautiful affirmation of the present moment.
The script is just so clever and full of great one-liners.
The way Gil finally finds his voice as a writer by living his own story is a great arc.
The film is a magical and romantic journey.
The 'golden age' twist is the thematic heart of the movie.
The performances are all fantastic.
The ending is a perfect, rainy Parisian dream.
A charming and thought-provoking film.
The way the movie uses history to explore a modern dilemma is brilliant.
The film is a beautiful and funny reminder to appreciate the here and now.
The final scene is a perfect example of understated romance.
The movie is a delightful and intelligent romp through time.
The central concept is so original and well-executed.
The casting of the historical figures is a stroke of genius.
The ending is a beautiful and satisfying conclusion to Gil's adventure.
A truly magical film.
The way the film explores the allure of the past is so relatable.
The movie is a visual and literary delight.
The final scene is a quiet and perfect end to a beautiful story.
The film is a charming and witty exploration of nostalgia.
The ending is a beautiful reminder that happiness is a choice you make in the present.
The script is one of Woody Allen's best.
The way Gil's journey through the past helps him fix his present is a great narrative.
The film is a magical realist masterpiece.
The 'golden age' theme is explored with such wit and intelligence.
The performances are a delight to watch.
The ending is a perfect, romantic sigh of a conclusion.
